description: From Late Latin syntagma, from Ancient Greek σύνταγμα (súntagma, “orderly arrangement”), from συντάσσω (suntássō, “arrange together”, “to order”).

entries.meaning: (linguistics) A constituent segment within a text, such as a word or a phrase that forms a syntactic unit.
examples: The syntagma “the God of peace” (in Greek ὁ Θεὸς τῆς εἰρήνης) occurs in all undisputed Pauline letters.

entries.meaning: (semiotics) An arrangement of units that together bears a meaning.
examples: To combine a sequence of shots into a larger syntagma, there has to be a connection between the successive shots.

entries.meaning: (history) A Macedonian phalanx fighting formation consisting of 256 men with long spears (sarissae).
examples: The men forming the syntagma were arranged in a square of sixteen files of sixteen.
